title: Can you spot the AI-generated Matterhorn?
displayTitle: Can you spot the AI-generated Matterhorn?
body: Let's start with a little challenge. One of these images has been generated with the image generation model Google Imagen 4, a recent example of generative AI models. The other one is a photograph taken by a human. Can you tell which one it is?
instruction: Choose the image which you think is AI-generated. No worries, you are not under evaluation (just yet) .
ariaQuestion: Which of these is the Matterhorn?

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct: That is correct! Congratulations, you identified the AI-generated Matterhorn! This image is generated with Google Imagen 4, while the other one is a real photo from www.pexels.com.

_incorrect.notFinal: That's not quite right. Try again!
_incorrect.final: That's incorrect . Seems like the model fooled you and the image you selected is a real photograph acquired from pexels.com (no personal credits). But I must admit it was quite difficult due to the small size of the images.

_comment: You only need to include _buttons if you want to override the button labels that are set in course.json

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

displayTitle: The Turing Test: An early IQ test for computers
body: Developed by Alan Turing (1912-1954) a British mathematician and the father of computer science.
instruction: Scroll through the dialogue to learn more.

_items.text: So, Alan, we just tried to distinguish between a real photo and an AI-generated one. What does that have to do with intelligence?
That's an excellent question! It gets to the heart of what Turing wondered in 1950: Can a machine be so good at imitating human intelligence that we can't tell the difference?
So, he created a test for that?

Yes, it's now known as the Turing Test. The basic idea is this: if a computer can engage in dialogue with a human without being detected as a computer, we can say it possesses a level of intelligence.
So, instead of images, it's about conversation?

Yes, in your image test, you were the judge, trying to decide if the 'output' (the image) was human-made or machine-made. The Turing Test simply expands that idea to conversation. Can a computer create conversational output that is indistinguishable from a human's?
Okay, I think I get it. So, the goal is to create a computer that can convincingly resemble human-like intelligence?

Exactly! And as AI gets more advanced, AI-generated images, text and videos will be harder and harder to identify. Of course you know that this conversation is pre-scripted, but new models like ChatGPT are so convincing, that they pass my test with ease.

title: What is AI?
body: The Turing Test is a very helpful analogy, but Artificial Intelligence is more than just mimicking humans.

_items.title: Deal with different problems and environments
_items.body: At its core, AI seeks to create machines that can perform tasks that typically require human intelligence. This includes things like understanding language, recognizing patterns, solving problems, and making decision.

_items.title: Learning and adapting
_items.body: Modern AI emphasizes enabling machines to learn from data and experience, similar to our brain. This involves writing programs that allow the AI to improve its performance over time through exposure to data and feedback.

_items.title: Autonomy
_items.body: AI aims to create intelligent systems that can operate with a degree of independence from humans. This means the AI can make decisions and take actions without explicit instructions for every situation.

_items.title: Explainability
_items.body: AI models can be so complex that even their creators may not fully understand how they arrive at decisions, creating a "black-box" scenario. This lack of understanding about the internal operations of AI systems raises concerns.

title: How do machines learn?
body: Artificial intelligence is the overarching field that aims to develop intelligent machines.  If we consider AI as the "brain", machine learning can be seen as the process through which the AI acquires the necessary abilities. But how do machines learn?
instruction: Use the arrows below to explore different types of machine learning.
mobileInstruction: Select the plus icon followed by the next arrow to find out more.

_items.title: Supervised Learning: Learning with a Teacher
_items.body:
Supervised learning is like learning with a teacher. The algorithm - the AI - is given examples with correct answers, also called labeled data.

For instance, it might be shown thousands of pictures of apples, each labeled 'apple', and pictures of bananas, labeled 'banana'. The goal is for the AI to learn the patterns so it can correctly identify apples or bananas in new, unseen pictures. Early spam filters are a common example for supervised learning.

_graphic.alt: Diagram illustrating supervised learning with labeled data leading to a predictive model.

_items.title: Unsupervised Learning: Finding Patterns on Its Own
_items.body:
Unsupervised learning is like giving the AI system a big box of mixed-up items and asking it to sort them without telling it how. The AI looks for similarities and differences on its own to group the items. In this case, the items have no label to draw conclusions from.

The AI system might group them by color, size, or shape. This is used to discover hidden patterns or structures in data, such as customer segmentation. Recommendations on Netflix or Spotify are common examples.

_graphic.alt: Diagram illustrating unsupervised learning finding patterns in unlabeled data.

_items.title: Deep Learning: Adding more Layers
_items.body:
Deep learning is a more advanced version that unlocks more complex tasks and higher performance. Imagine trying to teach a computer to recognize a cat in a picture. With regular machine learning, you might have to manually tell the computer what to look for – pointy ears, whiskers and a tail. Deep learning, on the other hand, learns those features automatically by detecting them throughout several layers.

Deep learning is often used for image recognition. Consider the layers in the image: In the first layer, the network might just detect edges and corners. The next layer combines those edges to form shapes. And the next layer combines the shapes to recognize cat features. Finally, the last layer puts it all together and says, 'That's a cat!

_graphic.alt: Diagram illustrating deep learning with a cat.

title: Quiz: Learning Types
body: An AI system is tasked with identifying defective products on an assembly line. It is trained using a large dataset where each product image is already labeled as 'defective' or 'not defective'. Which type of machine learning is being used?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} which applies, then select Submit.
ariaQuestion: An AI system is trained to identify defective products using images labeled 'defective' or 'not defective'. Which machine learning type is this?

_feedback.title: Learning Type Explanation
_feedback.altTitle: Feedback on your answer about machine learning types.
_feedback.correct: That's right! This scenario describes Supervised Learning. The AI is 'supervised' because it learns from a dataset where each example (product image) is already tagged with the correct answer or label ('defective' or 'not defective').

_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite. Consider which learning type involves being explicitly told the correct answer for each piece of training data.
_incorrect.final: The correct answer is Supervised Learning. This method is used when you have a dataset with known outcomes or labels. Unsupervised Learning would be used if the AI had to find patterns in unlabeled product images (e.g., group similar-looking defects without knowing what they are). Reinforcement Learning would involve the AI taking actions (like classifying a product) and receiving rewards or penalties to learn the best classification strategy over time. Algorithmic Trading is an application of various techniques, including AI, but isn't a fundamental learning type itself in this context.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal: This option is for questions with multiple correct answers, which isn't the case here. Please review the feedback for incorrect answers.
_partlyCorrect.final: This option is for questions with multiple correct answers, which isn't the case here. The correct answer is Supervised Learning. This method is used when you have a dataset with known outcomes or labels.

title: Training Data
displayTitle: Training data: The fuel for machine learning
body: Now you know what artificial intelligence is and how machines may learn from data. However, there is one major part missing: The training data. Real-world data, often produced by humans, then fed to machine learning algorithms. What are the three main considerations about training data?

_items.title: Quality
_items.body: The quality of the training data is crucial. If the data is noisy, incomplete, or biased, the model will learn these imperfections and perform poorly on new data.

_items.title: Quantity
_items.body: The amount of training data is also important. More data generally leads to a more accurate model, especially for complex tasks.

_items.title: Representativeness
_items.body: The training data should be representative of the real-world data that the model will be used on. If the training data is significantly different from the real-world data, the model may not generalize well.

body:
Sources:

Legg, Shane; Hutter, Marcus (2007): Universal Intelligence: A Definition of Machine Intelligence. DOI: https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.0712.3329

Sousa Antunes et al. (2024): Multidisciplinary Perspectives on Artificial Intelligence and the Law, DOI: https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-41264-6

Huawei Technologies (2023): Artificial Intelligence Technogoly, DOI: https://doi.org/10.1007/978-981-19-2879-6

title: Quick Recap
displayTitle: A quick recap on training data...
body: The training data used in machine learning is very important for this module, so let us briefly recap the main characteristics it should satisfy.

_items.title: Quality
_items.body: The quality of the training data is crucial. If the data is noisy, incomplete, or biased, the model will learn these imperfections and perform poorly on new data.

_items.title: Quantity
_items.body: The amount of training data is also important. More data generally leads to a more accurate model, especially for complex tasks.

_items.title: Representativeness
_items.body: The training data should be representative of the real-world data that the model will be used on. If the training data is significantly different from the real-world data, the model may not generalize well.

title: A quick memory game
body: I bet it has been a while since you played memory for the last time (without children). How about a quick game to illustrate gender biases?
feedback: Nice, you found all the matching cards.

title: Example Cases of Biases
displayTitle: Discrimination due to biases: Real examples
instruction: Click to learn the details about real examples of biases in AI training data

_next.ariaLabel: Select here to move to the next.

_items.title: Example
_items.body: Amazon's AI recruitment tool penalized female candidates due to biased training data.

_items.title: Bias
_items.body: Historical hiring data with a higher proportion of successful male applicants.

_items.title: Consequences
_items.body: Discrimination against qualified female applicants, perpetuating gender imbalance.

_items.title: Example
_items.body: Predictive policing algorithms target areas based on historical crime data.

_items.title: Bias
_items.body: Historical crime data reflects existing biases in policing, targeting low-income and minority neighborhoods.

_items.title: Consequences
_items.body: Increased arrests in targeted areas, reinforcing the perception of high crime and perpetuating a cycle of discrimination.

_items.title: Discrimination on the Basis of Skin Color
Example
_items.body: Facial recognition systems perform less accurately for individuals with darker skin tones.

_items.title: Bias
_items.body: Training datasets contain a disproportionately high number of images from specific ethnic groups or regions.

_items.title: Consequences
_items.body: Misidentification and unfair treatment in law enforcement and other applications of AI, perpetuating ethnicity-based discrimination.
